Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation2: The acquaintance is meeting a new person who seems shy and nervous in a social setting.
Story: I sat at the edge of the living room, my mother’s words echoing in my mind: “You’ll lead the ceremony this year. It’s important for our family.” The weight of tradition pressed on my shoulders, and I could already picture my relatives’ expectant faces, waiting for me to recite the prayers perfectly, to honor our ancestors as they always had. Just as I tried to steady my nerves, my phone buzzed. It was a message from a friend, asking me to come over and help welcome a new neighbor who was painfully shy. “You’re always so easy to talk to,” she wrote. “Can you help make her feel comfortable?” I knew how much it meant to be warm and open, to help someone feel at ease in a new place. But the thought of splitting my attention, of possibly disappointing my family or failing to be the friendly face my acquaintance needed, made my stomach twist. I could feel the expectations pulling me in opposite directions, each one important, each one demanding a different part of me.
